awd_titl_txt: Equitable Computer Science for All Learning Ecosystems: Developing Underserved Students' Computational Making Literacies Through Community-Embedded Out of School Time Programming
awd_abstract_narration:
At its core, the National Science Foundation's CSforAll initiative has the goal of creating the
infrastructure, pathways, and incentives that develop ecosystems for supporting and motivating all youth
to become computationally literate and pursue computer science-related degrees and careers. This
proposal makes a case for the extension of the CSforAll infrastructure to include the integration of out-of-school time (OST) learning projects into existing CSforAll funded grants by asking two questions: How
can we foster a community learning environment that recognizes, supports, and promotes computational
literacies as a desirable and accessible form of social capital by mentors, youth, and families? And how
do these community-level connections impact youth computational making learning opportunities,
participation, social networks, knowledge, and understanding? In Evanston, a partnership between
Northwestern University, the district, and the Evanston YMCA will work together to understand and answer these
questions by designing and operating a community-based computational making OST hub that provides
the learning activities and peer community needed to create an inviting and relevant environment for
students, caring adults, and educators to reorient their perception towards computer science-related
careers as desirable and achievable for youth in the community.

This proposal seeks to take advantage of a unique opportunity - the launch of a 1:1 middle grades tablet
initiative in a racially and socioeconomically diverse community actively engaged in addressing their
expanding achievement gap - to implement a community-based computational making OST hub and
reimagine how a community-embedded approach to OST designed to support youth and caring adults
(parents and mentors) can ignite youths' computational making participation. Specifically, this proposal
seeks to create a learning community that uses the computational thinking guided design process to
motivate and support students in the systemic creation of interactive objects that require the
integration of coding, digital fabrication, and visual design literacies to produce aesthetically powerful
and socially conscious solutions to student and community defined design challenges.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: Computer Science for All (CS for All)

por.por_cntn:
At the core, this grant was focused on working with an established Evanston community partner, McGaw YMCA to expand access to STEAM learning opportunities within the historic African American Fifth Ward, a community that bore the brunt of the city's school and community desegregation strategies as both the local school and YMCA were closed within 3 years of 1967, creating the present-day integrated school system that many Evanston residents seek.  Though several significance results and developments in the arcs of the work are named above, a few are worth elaborating here. 

 

First, we successfully collaborated with our partner to open  a second location of their middle school oriented maker space, MetaMedia., in the Fifth Ward open Monday thru Saturday staffed with a full time  trained STEAM informal educator workforce.  This new location served as a hub of collaboration between several Northwestern learning science faculty and community STEAM educators and organizations.

 

Second, our careful documentation of professional development processes has led to a line of research on teacher/educator learning in STEAM rich maker spaces that is poised to contribute key insights to the field through a recent Lucas foundation grant  that will support PI Shirin Vossoughi  in pursuing key questions around educator and teacher learning. 

 

Third,  we developed a unique collaboration between researchers, out-of-school educators and local artists to develop and share the results of our research in the form of pedagogical zines. These zines are available at: https://www.bluedandelion.org/zines and have been widely disseminated to maker-space and other educator and researcher networks. In addition to expanding authorship of research results to include educators and artists, the zines have developed a model for a genre that we hope to encourage in the field. This genre brings together research results and stories with visual arts to create meaningful resources for professional learning for out of school (as well as school based) educators working in STEAM education. A number of scholars and educational organizations have reached out to us and expressed interest in developing their own zines, which we hope Blue Dandelion can serve as a platform for supporting and disseminating. 

 

Fourth it is important to underscore the deepening of our partnership with the MetaMedia and YMCA educators and directors throughout the timeline of our work.  Our prior work with MetaMedia mentors and our attention to processes of partnership has opened up a powerful relationship  that provides a robust model of Research-Practice-Partnership work and the relational time and trust it takes to develop deep and equitable partnership. We are very excited to see where this partnership can take us in the coming years. As another indicator of the health of the model, a number of mentors and participants have either entered into or expressed interest in graduate school.   The pathway for RPP participants into higher education is one among many indicators of robust partnership that our program has observed and supported.

 


Last Modified: 03/06/2022
Modified by: Shirin Vossoughi

Image
  • Pedagogical zines blend collaborative research and art to create public resources for just educational practice.
    https://www.bluedandelion.org/zines

por.por_txt_cntn:
At the core, this grant was focused on working with an established Evanston community partner, McGaw YMCA to expand access to STEAM learning opportunities within the historic African American Fifth Ward, a community that bore the brunt of the city's school and community desegregation strategies as both the local school and YMCA were closed within 3 years of 1967, creating the present-day integrated school system that many Evanston residents seek.  Though several significance results and developments in the arcs of the work are named above, a few are worth elaborating here. 
 
First, we successfully collaborated with our partner to open  a second location of their middle school oriented maker space, MetaMedia., in the Fifth Ward open Monday thru Saturday staffed with a full time  trained STEAM informal educator workforce.  This new location served as a hub of collaboration between several Northwestern learning science faculty and community STEAM educators and organizations.
 
Second, our careful documentation of professional development processes has led to a line of research on teacher/educator learning in STEAM rich maker spaces that is poised to contribute key insights to the field through a recent Lucas foundation grant  that will support PI Shirin Vossoughi  in pursuing key questions around educator and teacher learning. 
 
Third,  we developed a unique collaboration between researchers, out-of-school educators and local artists to develop and share the results of our research in the form of pedagogical zines. These zines are available at: https://www.bluedandelion.org/zines and have been widely disseminated to maker-space and other educator and researcher networks. In addition to expanding authorship of research results to include educators and artists, the zines have developed a model for a genre that we hope to encourage in the field. This genre brings together research results and stories with visual arts to create meaningful resources for professional learning for out of school (as well as school based) educators working in STEAM education. A number of scholars and educational organizations have reached out to us and expressed interest in developing their own zines, which we hope Blue Dandelion can serve as a platform for supporting and disseminating. 
 
Fourth it is important to underscore the deepening of our partnership with the MetaMedia and YMCA educators and directors throughout the timeline of our work.  Our prior work with MetaMedia mentors and our attention to processes of partnership has opened up a powerful relationship  that provides a robust model of Research-Practice-Partnership work and the relational time and trust it takes to develop deep and equitable partnership. We are very excited to see where this partnership can take us in the coming years. As another indicator of the health of the model, a number of mentors and participants have either entered into or expressed interest in graduate school.   The pathway for RPP participants into higher education is one among many indicators of robust partnership that our program has observed and supported.
